moves.1... e5 2. g3 d5 3. Bg2 Nf6 4. b3 c5: Black is trying to get full control of the center
moves.5. Bb2 Nc6 6. Ne2 Be7 7. O-O O-O 8. c4: Finally white starts challenging black for the center
moves.8... Be6 9. d3 Qb6 10. Na3 Rad8 11. Bc3: black controls the dark squares to compensate for the weak dark square bishop
moves.13... Qc7 14. Nc2 Qd7 15. Nf4 Bf5 16. h3: Black threatens to remove the defender of d3
moves.17. g4: It is very dangerous to advance the castle pawns. The King position could be threatened.
moves.17... Bxf4 18. Bxf4 Bg6 19. Bf3 h6 20. h: A lesson: Never atack your opponent king with your castled pawns.
moves.20... Rfe8 21. h5 Bh7 22. g5 hxg5 23. Bx: And now a big threat is mounting. The white King no longer has its protective shield
moves.25. Bxf6 gxf6 26. Ne1 Kh8: A great move. Opening a file so that a rook can develop.
moves.27. f4 Reg8+: The onslaught starts. The only option is 28 Ng2
moves.28. Ng2 Qh3 29. Rf2 Nxd3 30. Bxd3 Bxd3 3: White tries to make threats on its own. The idea is to advance the f pawn and deliver mate on h6. So black has to eliminate this threat before resuming the attack.
moves.31... f5 32. a3 Be4: Putting more pressure on the white king
moves.34. b4 Rh4: 34.... Rh4! totally destroys white defenses. If 35. Nxh4 then 35.... Qh1 . The threat is mate on h1
moves.35. Kf1 Qh1+ 36. Ke2 d3+: White to avoid mate would have to sacrifice its queen
